sermons.title: Jesus: the Voice of Truth
sermons.summary:
The passage emphasizes Jesus' mission to bear witness to the truth, as He stated during His interrogation by Pilate, who was more concerned with Jesus' kingship. Jesus' focus on truth contrasts with Pilate's political concerns. The truth, defined as that which is factual and real, is embodied by God, who is alone and the creator of all. Humanity's sin and its consequences are also truths that are evident in our lives, as stated in Romans 5:12.

Despite the grim reality of sin, the Bible provides hope by declaring that God would manifest in flesh to take away our sins, as prophesied in Micah 5:2 and confirmed by the angel Gabriel in Matthew 1:21. Jesus, embodying the fullness of God (Colossians 2:9), took on a body to destroy sin, reconciling us to God through His death (Colossians 1:21-22). Belief in this truth, as presented in the Bible, is essential for salvation.

The passage warns against spiritual blindness, likening it to Cotard's syndrome, where individuals deny their own existence. To accept the truth, one must repent and be baptized in Jesus' name for the remission of sins, receiving the Holy Ghost as stated in Acts 2:38. This truth promises a new sinless body, a renewed spirit, and a heavenly home.

Jesus' mission was to testify to this truth, which surpasses all earthly concerns, including kingship. Embracing this truth grants freedom, as stated in John 8:32. The message encourages honoring and loving the truth, which Jesus prioritized over political matters, and assures that embracing this truth brings spiritual freedom and renewal.

sermons.title: Shining with the Glory of God
sermons.summary:
The passage highlights the transformative power of God's presence as exemplified by Moses, whose face shone after communing with God, contrasting with modern notions of beauty tied to cosmetics. Moses' radiant face symbolizes spiritual beauty achieved through deep, undistracted fellowship with God. His glowing skin is attributed to his direct conversations with God, illustrating that true spiritual glow comes from a relationship with the divine, unlike King Nebuchadnezzar, whose fall into madness reflected his distance from God.

The narrative stresses that God's word is potent and transformative, as seen in Moses' renewal. The distractions of contemporary life, particularly digital addictions, hinder Christians from experiencing this transformation. The call is to reclaim time for Jesus, promising that focused time in God's presence leads to spiritual radiance and fulfillment.

This concept extends to the "beauty of holiness," where God's beauty shines through those who worship and spend time with Him. Modern beauty industries pale in comparison to the glory that comes from a godly life. The passage criticizes the overemphasis on physical beauty and encourages seeking the beauty of Jesus' glory.

Moses’ intercession for Israel exemplifies his humility and dedication. His shining face was a result of his deep intercessory prayer for the people, showing that spending time in God’s presence for others brings spiritual radiance. Moses’ humility is further highlighted by his use of a veil to divert attention from himself to God.

Finally, the text underscores that while the Law of Moses had glory, it was limited by human sin. The true and unimpeded glory comes through Jesus Christ, whose sacrifice removes the veil of sin, allowing believers to reflect God's glory fully. The call is to embrace the new covenant through Jesus, experiencing transformation from glory to glory.

sermons.title: The God who Gives
sermons.summary:
The principle of giving and receiving is deeply ingrained in the fabric of creation itself, as illustrated by the abundance and generosity of nature. Just as the sun, water, soil, and even deserts give forth their blessings, God expects us to give back to Him in abundance.

Our foremost offering to God is our lives themselves. In the same way that God gave us life, we are called to present ourselves as living sacrifices, wholly devoted to His service. This includes dedicating our time, talents, and resources to His kingdom.

Abraham's willingness to offer his son Isaac and Hannah's vow to dedicate her son Samuel are powerful examples of giving back to God the very lives He has blessed us with. Similarly, Anna's lifelong devotion to serving God in the temple demonstrates the profound impact of giving one's time abundantly to the Lord.

When it comes to material wealth, we are reminded of Jesus' own sacrifice – though rich, He became poor for our sake, that through His poverty we might become rich in Him. Generosity is not only about monetary wealth but also about the attitude of the heart. God delights in a cheerful giver, one who gives freely and joyfully, without reservation.

The story of the miserly man who learns the joy of giving underscores the transformative power of generosity. Just as God gave His Son out of love for the world, we are called to emulate His sacrificial love by giving generously to others.

Ultimately, our giving reflects our faith and trust in God's provision. As we sow bountifully, we can trust that God will make all grace abound toward us, ensuring that we have more than enough to abound in every good work. Let us, therefore, give freely and generously, knowing that in doing so, we participate in God's eternal principle of giving and receiving.

sermons.title: Going to Jerusalem
sermons.summary:
The journey of Philip to meet the Ethiopian eunuch underscores the divine orchestration of God's plan to reach hearts and souls with the Gospel message. Despite the thriving revival in Samaria, Philip's immediate obedience to the Spirit's leading took him to the desert road where he encountered the seeking heart of the Ethiopian eunuch.

The Ethiopian's journey to Jerusalem for worship reflects a deep spiritual hunger and devotion, reminiscent of the psalmist's longing for the presence of God. In a world where many chase after temporal treasures, his pursuit of spiritual fulfillment in Jerusalem serves as a poignant reminder of the eternal significance of seeking God's kingdom above all else.

The encounter between Philip and the Ethiopian eunuch highlights God's inclusivity and impartiality in extending salvation to all nations. The eunuch's sincere engagement with Scripture in the desert setting demonstrates his genuine hunger for spiritual truth, which God honors by sending Philip to guide him.

Just as God revealed himself to Moses on Mount Sinai and to Elijah in the desert, the desert becomes a sacred space where God encounters his people in profound ways. In the barrenness of the desert, distractions are stripped away, allowing for a deeper communion with God and a clearer reception of his word.

The urgency of salvation is emphasized in the desert setting, where the harsh conditions serve as a reminder of the brevity of life and the need to prioritize eternal matters. Philip wastes no time in proclaiming the Gospel message, highlighting the singular importance of salvation through repentance, baptism in Jesus' name, and the reception of the Holy Spirit.

In a world filled with distractions and diversions, the call to "be still and know that I am God" resonates deeply in the desert environment. As believers navigate the spiritual desert of the world, may they heed the call to prioritize the proclamation of the Gospel message and lead others to encounter the living God.

sermons.title: The Rapture of the Church
sermons.summary:
The analogy of sowing seeds, both in agriculture and in spreading the Gospel, underscores the importance of consistent effort and diligence. Just as farmers sow seeds in faith, uncertain of the outcome but trusting in the process, Christians are called to sow the seeds of the Gospel without hesitation or delay.
In a world where many are unaware of the source of their sustenance, the faithful work of farmers ensures a steady food supply. Similarly, the spiritual labor of Christians, though often unnoticed or underappreciated, plays a vital role in spreading the message of salvation to all nations.
The urgency of sowing the Gospel is emphasized by the unpredictable nature of the future and the ever-present threat of spiritual opposition. Like the Apostle Paul, believers are called to seize every opportunity to share the Good News, regardless of the circumstances or perceived obstacles.
Just as farmers patiently wait for their seeds to yield a harvest, Christians sow the seeds of the Gospel with the expectation of a bountiful spiritual harvest in due time. Though the enemy may sow seeds of discord and falsehood, believers are called to remain steadfast in their mission, trusting in the Lord to ultimately bring about justice and redemption.
As we eagerly await the return of the Lord, let us continue to sow seeds of faith and hope, knowing that our labor in the Lord is never in vain. Just as the farmer diligently tends to his fields, so too must Christians faithfully sow the seeds of the Gospel, trusting in the Lord to bring about a harvest of souls for his kingdom.

sermons.title: The Rapture of the Church
sermons.summary:
The biblical metaphor of the thief in the night serves as a poignant reminder of the unpredictability of the Lord's return. Just as a thief does not announce their arrival, the day of the Lord will come unexpectedly. Vigilance is therefore paramount; those who diligently watch for the signs of the last days will be prepared for his coming. Among these signs are wars, natural disasters, pestilences, and the rise of false doctrine and false prophets, a warning reiterated by Jesus himself.
The signs of the end times are not always dramatic; everyday occurrences such as abundance in food, drink, and material possessions, along with the proliferation of knowledge and information, are also indicators. Despite the accessibility of knowledge, there remains a pervasive lack of understanding of the truth of salvation.
Crucially, the Gospel has been preached in every nation, marking a significant milestone in the countdown to the Lord's return. As believers, we are called to actively participate in spreading the Gospel, knowing that each soul reached brings us closer to the fulfillment of prophecy.
The return of the Lord Jesus will be like a thief coming to steal the most precious treasure on earth: the church. Once the church is removed, chaos will ensue, signaling the beginning of the end for the world as we know it. However, for believers, the rapture signifies the beginning of eternal life, peace, and blessings.
In light of these truths, let us remain vigilant and focused on the imminent return of the Lord, eagerly anticipating the day when we will partake in the first resurrection and reign with him for a thousand years.

sermons.title: He is not here, He is Risen!
sermons.summary:
The narrative begins with the biblical account of the Exodus, where the children of Israel departed from Egypt after applying the blood of the lamb to their doorposts. This act symbolizes a resurrection of a nation that had been in bondage for 430 years. The power of the lamb in this event foreshadows the resurrection of Jesus Christ. Just as the blood protected the Israelites from the destroyer in Egypt, Jesus' death and resurrection conquered death itself.
The physical death of Jesus, symbolized by his blood, defeated death and paved the way for resurrection. Paul's exclamation in Corinthians underscores this victory over death through Jesus Christ. Jesus' resurrection, a physical reality, was witnessed by over 500 disciples, ensuring the certainty of his victory over death.
Paul admonishes against doubting the physical resurrection of Jesus, as it is the foundation of Christian faith. He even names those who deny this truth, emphasizing its significance. The resurrection is the only hope for eternal life, made possible by God's sacrifice of his own Son.
Jesus' power to raise the dead is demonstrated in his miracle of raising Lazarus, foreshadowing his own resurrection. Unlike Lazarus, Jesus' flesh did not see corruption, affirming the reality of his physical resurrection. The apostles, including Peter, bore witness to this truth, and their testimony is the foundation of Christian faith.

sermons.title: The Voice of the Blood of Jesus
sermons.summary: Blood appears to have a voice, echoing from ancient times when Abel's blood cried out from the ground. Cain clearly underestimated the power of blood to appeal for justice when he killed his righteous brother. Blood is vital in keeping the body functioning properly and maintaining good health. Scripture emphasizes its role in atonement. Blood is never spilled in vain; it speaks a powerful language – the language of deliverance and salvation. In the prophecy of Jacob, the Messiah is intimately associated with blood. The Exodus narrative underscores its significance in safeguarding households. While human bloodlines are tainted by sin, Jesus offers a new and non-Adamic bloodline, through his flesh and blood that originated from the word of God. The blood of Jesus speaks powerfully. It says that Jesus is God(Acts 20:28). The blood of Jesus speaks better things than that of Abel, because it took away the sins of the whole world. Through the blood of Jesus, sins are absolved, and debts to death paid. Heaven reverberates with praise for the blood's power to cleanse and redeem. Just as blood circulates within us, Jesus' blood continually offers purification to sinners and saints. Its call remains: "...the blood of Jesus Christ his Son cleanseth us from all sin” (I John 1:7).

sermons.title: Is the Flesh of Jesus God?
sermons.summary:
Sometimes, in order to better elucidate a question that may be difficult for some One God
Christians to answer, it is helpful to formulate the question and meditate on it in light of the
scriptures. One way to answer this question is by reminding ourselves that we put on the same
body of the Lord in baptism. “For as many of you as have been baptized into Christ have put
on Christ” (Galatians 3:27). We can reinforce this scripture with another one to drive home
the point that we do indeed put on the literal body of the Lord with which we can enter
heaven. “Who shall change our vile body, that it may be fashioned like unto his glorious body,
according to the working whereby he is able even to subdue all things unto himself” (Phil
3:21). Now, once it is clear that we will have the same body as the Lord Jesus had on this
earth, and still has in heaven, it becomes easier to answer the question: is the flesh of Jesus
God? Obviously, the answer is that the flesh of Jesus cannot be reduced to all that is God for
that would mean we ourselves have put on “God-flesh”. This is why it is so important to
employ precise biblical language, or we will be in danger of courting false doctrine. Let us
explore this theme further.

sermons.title: What is the Relation of the Spirit of God to His Flesh and Blood?
sermons.summary:
This sermon explores the relationship between the Spirit of God and His flesh and blood. It begins by establishing that God, being spirit, cannot be made into anything. As stated in John 1:14, his word was made flesh. This distinction is crucial because God's essence is eternal and immutable, as affirmed in Malachi 3:6.
The explanation delves into the scripture in 1 Timothy 6:16 which speaks of Jesus having immortality. How can Jesus have immortality when he died on the Cross? The answer is that when we say “Jesus”, we are speaking about the Spirit in the flesh. Hence Jesus has immortality in his Spirit, but not in the flesh. This interpretation is supported by passages such as Romans 8:11, which speaks of the Spirit of God raising Jesus from the dead. It emphasizes the importance of distinguishing between the mortal flesh and the immortal Spirit of Jesus.
The discourse warns against ancient heresies such as Marcionism and Docetism, which denied the reality of Jesus' physical body and his suffering and death. It underscores the biblical teaching that Jesus was genuinely man, with a corporeal body subject to suffering and death. The rejection of these heretical views is grounded in the biblical accounts of Jesus' physical resurrection and His post-resurrection appearances to His disciples (Luke 24:39).
Furthermore, the sermon emphasizes the importance of understanding the relationship between the flesh and blood of Jesus and the Spirit of God. It refutes the notion of "spirit flesh" and asserts that Jesus truly died on the cross. It highlights the necessity of the Holy Spirit for spiritual life, even after baptism. The text emphasizes the vital role of the Spirit in giving life, contrasting it with the limitations of the flesh. Ultimately, it warns against reducing the Spirit of God to the flesh and blood of God alone, and the flesh and blood of God to the Spirit of God alone – as that would be a heresy.

sermons.title: The Gospel not After Man
sermons.summary:
The sermon on Galatians 1:11 emphasizes the divine origin of the Gospel message. It starts by defining the Gospel as the story of God manifesting in the flesh, dying for humanity's sins, rising from the dead, and living within believers through the Holy Spirit. This Gospel, it asserts, was revealed by Jesus himself and was not conceived by humans.

The narrative highlights the mystery of the Gospel, which was hidden from prophets and apostles until Jesus personally revealed it. Despite their role in conveying God's messages, they did not fully comprehend the significance of the Gospel until later. Satan's efforts to obscure the Gospel from humanity are also noted, underscoring the importance of divine intervention in sharing the message.

The sermon emphasizes Paul's personal experience of receiving the Gospel directly from Jesus, rather than through human intermediaries. This underscores the uniqueness and authenticity of the Gospel, which is not passed down as an inheritance from others but is a direct gift from God.

In the context of contemporary challenges and societal trends described in 2 Timothy 3:1–5, the sermon emphasizes the enduring power of the Gospel for those who have received it directly from God. It asserts that Jesus speaks to individuals in their own unique ways, making the Gospel accessible and relevant to people from all backgrounds and cultures.

sermons.title: The Gospel in the Court of Law
sermons.summary:
The sermon delves into the significance of the Law of God and its relationship to the Gospel of Jesus Christ. It begins by elucidating how the Law, given on Mount Sinai, represents the righteousness and holiness of God. Unlike human laws, the Law of God is unchanging and shows no mercy. The severity of the Law is illustrated through examples such as the punishment of death for breaking its commands.

However, the sermon highlights that the Law, despite its strictness, points to the Gospel of Jesus Christ. While the Law condemned and killed people for their sins, it ultimately paved the way for the arrival of Jesus, who fulfilled its demands. The birth of Jesus in Bethlehem stands in stark contrast to the thunderous events at Mount Sinai, signifying the transition from fear and judgment to love, peace, and mercy.

The narrative progresses to discuss how the Law played a crucial role in the arrest and condemnation of Jesus and the apostle Paul. Despite their innocence, both were subjected to trials and judgment by the Law. However, their condemnation ultimately served to fulfill the demands of the Law, leading to the redemption of humanity.

The sermon also touches upon the role of the Romans as a reluctant third party in the trials of Jesus and Paul. While the Romans were hesitant to pass judgment, their involvement ultimately facilitated the fulfillment of the Law's demands.

In conclusion, the sermon emphasizes the ongoing conflict between the Gospel and the world, with the Gospel often facing trial and opposition. However, through the ministry of reconciliation, believers are called to proclaim the message of Jesus Christ, which offers forgiveness and peace with God. The narrative underscores the transformative power of the Gospel, which brings reconciliation between humanity and God, ultimately triumphing over the demands of the Law.

sermons.title: God Also Hath Highly Exalted Him
sermons.summary:
The sermon centers on the exaltation of Jesus Christ, emphasizing the unparalleled significance of his name. Drawing from Philippians 2:9-10, the preacher highlights that God has highly exalted Jesus and bestowed upon him a name above every other name. This exaltation is rooted in the fact that Jesus is the manifestation of God Himself.

Despite God's numerous mighty works, including the creation of the universe and the deliverance of Israel from Egypt, it is Jesus who receives the highest honor. The reason for this, as the sermon explains, is that Jesus is the vessel through whom God performed His most exalted work ever.

The narrative delves into the paradoxical nature of Jesus' exaltation, contrasting human rejection and humiliation with divine elevation. Despite the degradation Jesus faced during his earthly ministry, God exalted him above every name. The sermon emphasizes that the more Jesus is brought down by humans, the higher God will exalt him.

Using the example of Saul's conversion on the road to Damascus, the preacher illustrates the transformative power of encountering the exalted Jesus. Saul, who initially persecuted followers of Jesus, was profoundly changed when he encountered the exalted Jesus, leading to his confession of Jesus as God.

In conclusion, the sermon urges listeners to acknowledge and exalt Jesus as the manifestation of God Himself. It emphasizes the necessity of repentance, baptism in Jesus' name, and receiving the Holy Spirit to please God and conquer the challenges of the world. The central message is that Jesus, exalted by God above all names, is deserving of honor and reverence as the one true God.

sermons.title: The Kingdom of Heaven Like a Mustard Seed
sermons.summary:
The parable of the mustard seed, as described in Matthew 13:31-32, illustrates the concept of the Kingdom of Heaven. Despite its small size, the mustard seed grows into a large tree, providing shelter for birds. This parable symbolizes the exponential growth and impact of the Kingdom of Heaven.

The sermon draws a comparison between the mustard seed and an aspirin tablet, highlighting the disparity in their perceived effectiveness. While an aspirin tablet may relieve a headache temporarily, the mustard seed represents the transformative power of Jesus Christ. Just as the mustard seed grows into a large tree, the influence of Jesus can expand exponentially in the lives of believers.

The narrative emphasizes the importance of faith, using examples such as the parents of Moses and the story of David. Despite their humble beginnings, these individuals exhibited faith as small as a mustard seed, leading to remarkable outcomes. Similarly, believers are encouraged to have faith in the power of Jesus Christ to transform lives.

The sermon also addresses the issue of congregational size, reassuring believers that greatness is not determined by numbers but by the presence of Jesus Christ. The example of the apostle Paul, often described as small in stature, underscores the idea that true greatness comes from the mustard seed, representing Jesus.

In conclusion, the sermon encourages believers to focus on planting the mustard seed of Jesus Christ in the hearts of others, trusting in its transformative power. By allowing Jesus to grow within them, believers can experience the fullness of salvation and allow His influence to permeate every aspect of their lives.

sermons.title: The Purpose of Fasting
sermons.summary:
The sermon delves into the significance of fasting, drawing primarily from Deuteronomy 8:3, which highlights that God humbled Israel through hunger, introducing the concept of fasting as a means of subordinating the desires of the flesh to appreciate God. The origin of pride is linked to a corrupt spirit, fueled by the flesh and its reliance on food.

The narrative refers to the Israelites, who, after 430 years of slavery in Egypt, expected a lavish feast on their journey to the promised land. However, God, testing their ability to prioritize spiritual needs over physical desires, provided manna. The kingdom of God, the sermon emphasizes, is not about meat and drink but righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost.

The war between the flesh, craving earthly comforts, and the spirit, yearning for God, is explored. Fasting is portrayed as a practice that trains the flesh to submit to the spirit. The sermon links the Lord's forty-day fast to this war, emphasizing that Jesus, not having a flesh from the earth, was not subject to earthly cravings.

The act of fasting is presented as a declaration that the earth will not be the master but Jesus, the God of the Spirit. Quoting John 8:23-24, the distinction between being from beneath (earthly) and from above (spiritual) is highlighted. The death of Judas is cited as a cautionary example of prioritizing the stomach (earthly) over spiritual matters.

The scripture in Deuteronomy 8:3 is dissected further, emphasizing that man lives not by bread alone but by every word that proceeds out of the mouth of the Lord. Fasting is portrayed as a demonstration of awareness of our origin, created by the word of God. The act of fasting, the sermon contends, signifies spiritual maturity and investment in a better spiritual tomorrow.

The sermon concludes by referencing Mark 2:19-20, where Jesus speaks about fasting in the context of the bridegroom being taken away. This is interpreted as a recognition that, in the absence of the direct presence of the divine (the bridegroom), fasting becomes a crucial spiritual discipline.

sermons.title: Jesus: The Desire of All Nations
sermons.summary:
The sermon centers on Haggai 2:7, which declares that God will shake all nations, and the desire of all nations, referring to Jesus, will come. The preacher emphasizes the transient nature of worldly stability, likening it to shaky ground that crumbles in the face of divine shaking. The call is for people to place their trust in Jesus, described as the desire of all nations.

The analogy of walking on dry ground amidst the sea, similar to the Israelites' experience after God shook Egypt, is used to convey the safety and stability found in Jesus. Believers, founded on Jesus as the cornerstone, are encouraged to navigate life's challenges with the surety that comes from their faith.

The sermon underscores the inevitability of God shaking all nations, highlighting the futility of trusting in human structures or leaders. Drawing lessons from the political situation in Bolivia, the preacher warns against putting faith in political figures, emphasizing that Jesus will shake all nations.

The passage discusses the curse of trusting in humans and contrasts it with the blessing of trusting in the Lord. The metaphor of the heath, specifically the Arar plant, serves as a warning against deceptive appearances and the danger of trusting in worldly entities.

Finally, the preacher interprets the filling of "this house with glory" as a reference to the Temple of believers' bodies. The New Covenant, as articulated in Jeremiah 31:33-34, is cited to emphasize the dwelling of God within believers. The ultimate vision is of the earth being filled with the knowledge of the Lord as the waters cover the sea, portraying a future where God lives in every individual.

The sermon concludes with an exhortation for believers to prepare for the coming of the desire of all nations, urging them to welcome Jesus into their lives as the ultimate fulfillment of God's promise.

sermons.title: Call for Simon
sermons.summary:
The sermon focuses on Acts 11:13-14, using the example of Cornelius, who saw an angel but needed to hear words from Peter for salvation. Angels are powerful beings, but angels lack the experience of salvation and the transformative power of Jesus' words. They are not commissioned to preach the Gospel; only humans, having experienced salvation, can effectively convey the words of Jesus.

The preacher highlights the transformative power of the words of Jesus, drawing a parallel with the tongues of fire on the Day of Pentecost. This event, described in Acts 2:2-3, signifies the entry of Jesus' words into believers as tongues of fire, enabling them to become messengers of salvation. The preacher asserts that angels lack this experience, and evil angels, being associated with lies, are forbidden to convey any message.

The phrase "Call for Simon" is central to the sermon, representing a call to those who know about sin and transformation through the Lord Jesus Christ. Simon, or Peter, had received the words of Jesus during Pentecost. The preacher sees this as a representation of all Christians today, emphasizing that despite strengths, weaknesses, and contradictions, believers carry the deposit of Jesus' words for salvation.

The sermon stresses the importance of responding to the call to share the words of salvation, comparing believers to spiritual first responders. The responsibility, likened to that of Jonah, requires believers to be vigilant, watchful, and always ready to respond to the call. The urgency of salvation is compared to a matter of life and death, and believers are encouraged to see themselves as spiritual first responders, always ready to share the transformative words of Jesus for the salvation of others.

sermons.title: Ezra Prepared his Heart
sermons.summary:
In this sermon on Ezra 7:10, the focus is on Ezra's preparation to seek, do, and teach the law of the Lord. The context is the end of the Babylonian captivity as prophesied by Jeremiah. Ezra, a captive in Babylon, understood the significance of the times through his knowledge of God's word.

The preacher emphasizes the importance of understanding the prophetic clock of God, referring to Deuteronomy 28:13, which speaks of being the head and not the tail if one heeds the commandments of the Lord. Regardless of one's circumstances, knowing God's timing is crucial.

Ezra's preparation involved seeking the word of God diligently. The sermon cites Isaiah 26:9, highlighting the idea that the gifts of God can only be understood through a knowledge of His word. The preacher draws a parallel with the condition for Israel to inherit the land of Canaan, emphasizing that forsaking the covenant led to their exile. Ezra, learning from this, prepared his heart to seek the Lord to prevent a recurrence.

Moreover, Ezra didn't stop at seeking; he also implemented what he learned from the word of God. The sermon emphasizes the importance of not only knowing but also obeying the word of God. The example is given of those who knew the word but lacked love for God, as mentioned in John 5:42.

The sermon concludes with Ezra's determination to teach the word of God to Israel. Teaching is presented as a calling of sacrifice, love, and labor. The preacher underscores the joy of seeing others grow in knowledge and grace. The role of a teacher is described as being patient, adaptable, and prayerful, yet ready to challenge the rebellious for the sake of the truth, drawing inspiration from Ezra's actions in Ezra 10:1.

Overall, the sermon encourages the congregation to follow Ezra's example of preparation—seeking, doing, and teaching the word of God. It stresses the relevance of understanding God's timing and the need for both personal obedience and a commitment to teaching others.

sermons.title: What Doth the Lord Require of Thee?
sermons.summary:
This sermon on Micah 6:8 explores the profound requirements that the Lord has set for humanity: to do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God. The preacher emphasizes that God has clearly shown what is good; it's not a mystery hidden from humanity. This revelation is not exclusive to any particular group but is accessible to all, as evident from the examples of various biblical figures like Adam, Abel, Seth, Noah, and Job who knew and demonstrated what was good.

The sermon highlights the role of conscience as a God-given arbiter of good and bad, emphasizing the need for individuals to train their consciences to be spiritually fit. Going against one's conscience is deemed destructive.

The concept of doing justly is explained as aligning one's decisions with the will of God. Knowledge of the law, both earthly and divine, is crucial for such just actions. The distinction between ethics (theory of justice) and morality (action based on ethics) is drawn, emphasizing that acting justly requires knowledge of God's word.

Loving mercy is presented as more than just forgiveness; it involves having the power to seek justice but choosing to forgive. The example of Joseph forgiving his brothers, who had committed serious sins against him, is cited as an illustration of true mercy.

Walking humbly with God is defined as understanding one's true self outside of the salvation and grace of Jesus Christ. Humility involves recognizing one's origin in sin and acknowledging God's embodiment of humility in Jesus Christ.

The sermon concludes by presenting Jesus Christ as the perfect embodiment of Micah 6:8, as He is goodness personified, just in His actions, and the ultimate manifestation of God's mercy. Belief in Jesus and acceptance of His goodness, mercy, justice, and humility lead to baptism and a life aligned with the will of Jesus, fulfilling Micah 6:8. The congregation is encouraged to look to Jesus in an evil world and find in Him the revelation of what is truly good.

sermons.title: Then Cometh the Devil
sermons.summary:
This sermon on Luke 8:12 emphasizes the regularity of the Devil's attempts to snatch away the word of God whenever it is preached. Drawing an analogy with birds following a farmer who is sowing seeds, the preacher underscores the constant presence of the Devil, who never misses a chance to interfere with the reception of God's word. The spiritual implication is that Christians need to take these seemingly harmless distractions seriously, as they represent unclean spirits sent to distract and steal the seed of the word of God.
The sermon delves into the various methods farmers use to protect their seeds from birds, comparing these to spiritual strategies for safeguarding the word of God. The importance of the word is emphasized, with a parallel drawn between the need for food for physical survival and the necessity of the word for spiritual life.
A key revelation presented is the "nuclear bomb" of revelations—the One God doctrine. Likening this doctrinal truth to a nuclear weapon that terrifies the Devil, the preacher suggests that the spiritual realm is profoundly affected when Christians grasp and embody the truth of the oneness of God.
The historical example of Moses confronting Pharaoh with the declaration of the one God is cited, highlighting the transformative power of this truth. The Devil's fear of Christians acquiring this doctrinal "weapon" is emphasized, suggesting that the Devil's strategic attendance at church services is to prevent believers from grasping this truth that could be destructive to his kingdom.
The sermon concludes by urging believers to be aware that the Devil targets the heart, where the word is deposited, emphasizing the need for a deep understanding of doctrinal truths. It encourages believers to prioritize what is needful, echoing the words of Jesus to Martha in Luke 10:41–42. Overall, the message serves as a call to spiritual vigilance, doctrinal depth, and a strategic understanding of the constant efforts of the Devil.

sermons.title: Young Man, I Say Unto Thee Arise
sermons.summary:
The sermon on Matthew 12:42 draws parallels between the Queen of Sheba's journey to seek the wisdom of Solomon and the response of the present generation to the wisdom of Jesus Christ. It emphasizes the condemning judgment the Queen of Sheba will have on the current generation for not responding adequately to the wisdom and invitation of Jesus.

The Queen of Sheba is portrayed as a seeker of divine wisdom who, despite being rich in material possessions, recognized her spiritual poverty and sought the wisdom of God. Her journey to Jerusalem, risking everything and taking a generous offering to Solomon, is presented as an act of great faith and humility. The contrast is made with the current generation that, despite hearing about Jesus' miraculous birth, healing power, sacrificial death, and imminent return, remains indifferent and hesitant to seek Him.

The audience is urged not to be condemned by the Queen of Sheba on the day of judgment. The importance of actively seeking Jesus, responding to His invitation, and humbling oneself in the process is highlighted. The sermon encourages believers to undertake a spiritual journey to Jesus, reminiscent of the Queen of Sheba's physical journey, and to ask questions that only Jesus can answer. Patience, faith, and hope in the journey to Jesus are emphasized as virtues that yield great benefits.

In conclusion, the congregation is invited to step down from their metaphorical thrones, risk everything, and go to the Lord Jesus Christ. The sermon urges a proactive and faith-filled response to the wisdom and invitation of Jesus, framing the Queen of Sheba as a model for all who seek God. The final call is to join in a collective journey to Jerusalem, ensuring that the Queen of Sheba does not condemn individuals for not responding to the greater wisdom presented in Jesus Christ.

sermons.title: The Judgement of the Queen of Sheba
sermons.summary:
The sermon on Matthew 12:42 draws parallels between the Queen of Sheba's journey to seek the wisdom of Solomon and the response of the present generation to the wisdom of Jesus Christ. It emphasizes the condemning judgment the Queen of Sheba will have on the current generation for not responding adequately to the wisdom and invitation of Jesus.

The Queen of Sheba is portrayed as a seeker of divine wisdom who, despite being rich in material possessions, recognized her spiritual poverty and sought the wisdom of God. Her journey to Jerusalem, risking everything and taking a generous offering to Solomon, is presented as an act of great faith and humility. The contrast is made with the current generation that, despite hearing about Jesus' miraculous birth, healing power, sacrificial death, and imminent return, remains indifferent and hesitant to seek Him.

The audience is urged not to be condemned by the Queen of Sheba on the day of judgment. The importance of actively seeking Jesus, responding to His invitation, and humbling oneself in the process is highlighted. The sermon encourages believers to undertake a spiritual journey to Jesus, reminiscent of the Queen of Sheba's physical journey, and to ask questions that only Jesus can answer. Patience, faith, and hope in the journey to Jesus are emphasized as virtues that yield great benefits.

In conclusion, the congregation is invited to step down from their metaphorical thrones, risk everything, and go to the Lord Jesus Christ. The sermon urges a proactive and faith-filled response to the wisdom and invitation of Jesus, framing the Queen of Sheba as a model for all who seek God. The final call is to join in a collective journey to Jerusalem, ensuring that the Queen of Sheba does not condemn individuals for not responding to the greater wisdom presented in Jesus Christ.

sermons.title: The Purpose of Unity
sermons.summary:
The sermon explores the theme of unity, emphasizing its importance and potential consequences based on biblical narratives. It begins by praising the beauty of unity, linking it to security, peace, progress, and prosperity. Psalm 133 is cited to illustrate the goodness and pleasantness of brethren dwelling together in unity, likening it to the anointing of the Holy Spirit.
The sermon then delves into the story of the Tower of Babel from Genesis 11, highlighting the unity the people had in language and speech. However, it warns that unity without consulting God can lead to disaster, drawing parallels with the cautionary tale of Lot and Jehoshaphat's discernment when facing united prophesies.
The Tower of Babel is presented as an example of unity that ignored God, leading to the loss of language, city, and unity itself. The sermon underscores that unity must align with God's will, quoting Genesis 1:28 about filling the earth and multiplying. It contrasts the disobedient unity of Babel with the united prayer of 120 disciples in Acts 2, leading to the outpouring of the Holy Spirit on Pentecost.
The purpose of unity is then discussed, focusing on Acts 2:1-2 and Joel 2:28 as the fulfillment of the greatest prophecy in the Bible—the outpouring of the Holy Spirit. The sermon argues that unity among believers striving for the faith of the gospel is a worthy purpose, referencing Philippians 1:27. The unity of the Apostles and early Christians in Jerusalem is presented as a positive example of unity bringing blessings and growth.
In conclusion, the sermon encourages believers to seek unity for the purpose of the outpouring of the Holy Spirit as in the day of Pentecost and striving together for the gospel, invoking divine favor and growth in the church. The hope is expressed for the Lord to grant a similar unity to believers in the present day.

sermons.title: Jesus – the Prince of Peace
sermons.summary:
The sermon explores the theme of peace during the Christmas season, focusing on Isaiah 9:6, which describes Jesus as the "Prince of Peace." It acknowledges the apparent disconnect between the traditional association of Christmas with peace and the ongoing wars and conflicts in the world. Despite this, the sermon assures believers that the hope for peace through Jesus Christ will not be in vain.

The message delves into the idea that the rejection of Jesus leads to conflicts, drawing from Luke 19 where Jesus laments over Jerusalem's impending destruction due to their failure to recognize the time of His visitation. The peace offered by Jesus is emphasized as distinct from worldly peace, and the verse from John 14:27 is cited to highlight this heavenly peace bestowed by Jesus.

The sermon extends beyond human conflicts to natural disasters, referencing the idea that the earth rebelled against humanity after human rebellion against God. However, it brings hope by suggesting that the message of Christmas promises a future where Jesus, as God, has control over storms, famines, and every natural disaster.

Additionally, the sermon addresses physical illnesses, portraying them as a consequence of Adam's rebellion. Yet, it offers hope by pointing to Jesus' sacrifice on the cross as a means of healing, drawing from Isaiah 53:5. Believers are encouraged to seek healing by acknowledging Jesus' sufferings for their well-being.

Finally, the sermon looks forward to the fulfillment of Isaiah 2:4, envisioning a day when Jesus, as King, will bring lasting peace to the nations. The anticipated reign of Jesus is presented as a time when war and violence will cease, and the sermon concludes with a call to eagerly await Jesus' return.

In summary, the sermon weaves together the theme of peace, encompassing conflicts, natural disasters, physical illnesses, and the anticipated return of Jesus as the ultimate Prince of Peace. Believers are encouraged to find peace in Jesus and anticipate a future without war or violence.

sermons.title: From Deacon to Preacher to Martyr: The Story of Stephen
sermons.summary:
The sermon delves into the life of Stephen, the first Christian martyr, drawing insights from Acts 6 and 7. Stephen's name, meaning "crown," becomes significant as he receives the crown of life for his martyrdom. The congregation is reminded of Revelation 2:10, where Jesus promises a crown of life to those who remain faithful unto death.

Initially chosen as one of the seven deacons to serve tables, Stephen's story emphasizes humility in accepting any role assigned by the Lord. The sermon highlights the qualifications for deacons, stressing honesty and being filled with the Holy Spirit. Stephen's qualities extend beyond serving tables, and he soon becomes a powerful preacher, demonstrating the importance of relying on the wisdom of the Holy Spirit rather than titles or natural gifts.

The message emphasizes the unique blessing of martyrdom, citing Revelation 6:9, where the souls of those slain for the word of God are honored. Stephen's life is presented as a testament to the power of being full of the Holy Spirit, enabling him to perform miracles and preach effectively.

The sermon concludes with Stephen's martyrdom, showcasing his vision of Jesus standing at the right hand of God. This unique posture signifies Jesus' approval and applause for Stephen's testimony. The congregation is encouraged to look steadfastly to heaven, following Stephen's example, and to keep testifying for Jesus, even unto death. Stephen's death is portrayed as glorious, with his last words echoing those of Jesus on the cross, asking God not to charge his persecutors with sin.

The overarching lessons include the importance of humility, relying on the Holy Spirit's wisdom, and the honor bestowed upon those who testify for Jesus. Stephen's life serves as an inspiration for believers to remain steadfast, even in the face of persecution, trusting in the ultimate victory of Christ.

sermons.title: The Power of the Word of God
sermons.summary:
The sermon focuses on the transformative power of the word of God, drawing parallels from Isaiah 55:10-11. The analogy presented is that, just as rain and snow from above nourish the earth, the word of God, emanating from a higher source—God's throne and mouth—nourishes the soul. The principle emphasized is the soul's dependence on the word of God for vitality, similar to how the earth relies on blessings from above.
The speaker underscores the necessity of the word of God, emphasizing that without it, the soul becomes parched and dry. The example of King Saul, who rebelled against the word of God, is used to illustrate how a lack of God's word can lead to a spiritual famine.
The sermon highlights the promises in the Bible, asserting that God's word never returns empty but accomplishes its intended purpose. Congregants are encouraged to express gratitude for the abundance of God's word and its continuous shower of blessings.
The sermon then transitions to the story of King Jehoshaphat, who, by sending teachers to spread the word of God, experienced protection and peace, as enemies were deterred from making war. The lesson drawn is that studying and humbling oneself before the word of God can lead to divine intervention and protection.
The narrative shifts to contrasting responses to the word of God, using the examples of Kings Jehoiakim and Josiah. Jehoiakim's disdain for the prophet Jeremiah's message led to a prophecy of his demise, which was fulfilled when Nebuchadnezzar attacked and killed him. On the other hand, Josiah responded to the word of God with humility and repentance, demonstrating that individual responses to God's word matter, even if collective change is challenging.
The sermon concludes by referencing the repentance of the people of Nineveh in response to the word of God, showing that collective change is possible. The overall message is a call to appreciate and respect the power of the word of God, acknowledging its ability to transform lives and bring about positive change when received with humility and obedience.

sermons.title: The Lord is My Shepherd
sermons.summary:
In this sermon based on Psalm 23, the speaker begins by emphasizing the profound declaration that "the Lord is my shepherd." This statement implies a conscious choice after trying various other "shepherds" in life—leaders, philosophies, or ideologies—and realizing that only Jesus suffices. The congregation is invited to collectively affirm, "The Lord is my shepherd." The assurance follows that in having the Lord as one's shepherd, there will be no lack.

The analogy of David as a shepherd for his sheep is presented, emphasizing David's role in soothing his sheep with heavenly music and risking his life for their safety. Drawing from John 10, the sermon highlights Jesus as the good shepherd who not only lays down his life for the sheep but also has the power to raise himself up.

Moving forward, the sermon explores Psalm 23:2-3, where David expresses his willingness to be led by God, emphasizing the importance of submission to the Lord's leadership. The metaphor of shepherd and sheep signifies submission, contrasting the Egyptians' rejection of shepherds, which is linked to their lack of submission.

The narrative then shifts to the shepherds in Luke 2, who are the first to hear about the birth of Jesus. The sermon underscores the significance of shepherds in biblical events, tying it to believers being shepherded by the Lord and also shepherding others.

Finally, the sermon touches on the timing of Jesus' birth, coinciding with the season when new lambs were born for Temple sacrifice. This aligns with Jesus being the Lamb of God, symbolizing sacrifice for sins. The sermon concludes by emphasizing the uniqueness of Jesus as both the Father and the Son, echoing John 10:18.

In summary, the sermon encourages a declaration of faith in Jesus as the great shepherd, emphasizes the importance of submission to His leadership, draws parallels between biblical shepherds and believers, and underscores the symbolic timing of Jesus' birth in connection with sacrificial lambs. The congregation is invited to collectively affirm Jesus as their shepherd.

sermons.title: Give Me Also Springs of Water: The Request of Achsah
sermons.summary:
Based on Joshua 15:16 and related verses, this sermon explores the story of Achsah, the daughter of Caleb, and draws spiritual lessons from her experience.
Caleb, Achsah's father, declares that whoever conquers Kirjathsepher will be given Achsah as a wife. This demonstrates the special nature of Achsah, and her eventual husband, Othniel (Caleb's younger brother), rises to the challenge, marrying her after conquering Kirjathsepher. The unconventional marriage aligns with the customs of the time and is not explicitly forbidden by the Mosaic law.
Achsah, symbolizing the church of Jesus Christ, later prompts her husband to ask her father for a field. This reflects the church's role in encouraging believers to seek blessings and guidance from their heavenly Father. Achsah's boldness in asking for a piece of land is likened to believers seeking a new body through baptism in Jesus' name. The metaphor extends to the necessity of constant spiritual nourishment, akin to water for a piece of land, emphasizing the importance of being filled with the Holy Spirit.
The sermon then delves into the story of Caleb in Joshua 14, highlighting his enduring passion for the blessings of God. Caleb, at 85 years old, boldly asks Joshua for the mountain promised to him by Moses years earlier. His request is granted, showcasing his unwavering faith and zeal for God's promises.
Achsah's subsequent request to Caleb for a blessing is linked to believers seeking the blessing of God in their lives. The importance of gratitude is emphasized, urging believers to thank God for past blessings. Achsah's specific request for springs of water represents believers asking for a continuous flow of the Holy Spirit from above and below, drawing parallels with the well-watered land of Canaan described in Deuteronomy.
In summary, the sermon encourages believers to boldly approach God, seek His blessings, express gratitude for past favors, and ask for a continuous flow of the Holy Spirit. The narrative of Achsah and Caleb serves as a metaphor for the relationship between believers and their heavenly Father, emphasizing faith, boldness, and the continuous pursuit of spiritual nourishment.

sermons.title: The Crowns of Victory a Christian's Eternal Reward
sermons.summary:
This sermon explores the profound significance of crowns in the Scriptures, beginning with an examination of five Hebrew words for crown in the Old Testament: Qodhqodh, Zer, Nezer, Atarah, and Kether. Each word reveals layers of meaning, symbolizing honor, authority, dedication, victory, and regal majesty. The exploration emphasizes that crowns in the Old Testament represent not only positions of authority but also symbols of consecration, victory, and regal honor.

Transitioning to the New Testament, the sermon delves into the promises of the five crowns awaiting faithful Christians. The Greek term "Stephanos," akin to the wreaths awarded in ancient competitions, is described as representing victory and triumph. The five crowns—Soul Winners Crown, Crown of Self-Denial, Crown of Righteousness, Crown of Life, and Crown of the Under Shepherd—each hold a unique promise, reflecting aspects of service, discipline, righteousness, endurance, and shepherding.

The Soul Winners Crown, mentioned in 1 Thessalonians 2:19, is portrayed as a source of hope, joy, and rejoicing, symbolizing the victory of bringing souls into the presence of the Lord at His coming. The Crown of Self-Denial, found in 1 Corinthians 9:25, is associated with mastery and victory, emphasizing the incorruptible reward for practicing self-discipline for the sake of Christ.

The Crown of Righteousness, as per 2 Timothy 4:8, symbolizes the wreath of victory worn by those excelling in righteousness, promising eternal honor from the righteous Judge to those eagerly awaiting His return. The Crown of Life, described in James 1:12, represents triumph over trials and challenges, a testament to the endurance and faithfulness of believers in the face of life's hardships.

Finally, the Crown of the Under Shepherd, mentioned in 1 Peter 5:4, symbolizes the crown of glory that awaits faithful shepherds in God's flock. As believers serve under the chief Shepherd, Jesus Christ, they are promised a crown that does not fade away, signifying eternal honor and glory.

The sermon concludes with a call to strive for these imperishable crowns with hearts full of love, service, endurance, and faithfulness, understanding that they are the eternal rewards from the chief Shepherd, Jesus Christ.

sermons.title: Thy Faith has Made Thee Whole
sermons.summary:
The sermon underscores the paramount importance of faith in the Christian journey. Starting with a biblical definition from Hebrews 11:1, faith is described not just as hope in God's promises but as a deep confidence that those promises will come to fruition. The sermon emphasizes that faith is a living and walking reality among believers, citing examples of biblical figures like Noah, Abraham, Moses, Elijah, and the apostles as exemplars of faith.
The narrative delves into the story of the woman with the blood issue, highlighting the potential consequences of misdirected faith, as she suffered for twelve years relying on physicians. The sermon cautions against placing hope where it may not yield positive results, emphasizing that faith in the name and power of Jesus Christ brings wholeness.
The story of blind Bartimaeus is presented as an illustration of remarkable faith, which not only recognizes the opportune time for healing but also has the power to bring the feet of Jesus to a complete stop. The credit for healing is given to the faith of individuals like Bartimaeus and the woman with the blood issue, emphasizing the integral role of faith in activating God's power.
The sermon extends to examples of faith exercised on behalf of others, such as the Roman centurion's plea for the healing of his servant and the Syrophoenician woman's faith on behalf of her daughter. These instances underscore the significance of compassion and concern for the less fortunate, demonstrating that great faith exercised on behalf of the poor and lowly brings praise from the Lord.
The conclusion of the sermon encourages believers to not only nurture faith for personal well-being but also to extend it to others, making a positive impact on the lives of those less fortunate. The title, "Thy faith has made thee whole," is echoed in the call to practice "Thy faith has made others whole," emphasizing the transformative and communal nature of faith.

sermons.title: You are the Temple of God
sermons.summary:
The sermon delves into the analogy of the wilderness in the days of Moses, drawing parallels to the Christian journey. The thirst experienced by the children of Israel for water in the wilderness becomes a metaphor for the Christian's thirst for the Holy Spirit. The key point is that just as water was the first and most acute need in the wilderness, seeking the Spirit of the Lord Jesus should be the primary concern for a Christian.

The biblical narrative from Numbers 20 is used to highlight the importance of persistently seeking the Holy Spirit. The children of Israel, faced with a lack of water, demanded it from Moses. The analogy suggests that Christians should pester the Lord with prayers and requests for the infilling of the Holy Spirit, acknowledging God's good intentions in providing this spiritual water.

The sermon also emphasizes the significance of the body as the temple of God, using the Corinthian Christians as an example. The Corinthians are criticized for living carelessly and not discerning the Lord's body, leading to some of them facing consequences. This leads to a discussion about the doctrine of the body as the temple of God, where God desires to dwell in His people.

The idea of the tabernacle in the wilderness is explored, emphasizing that God's original plan was for the tabernacle to be mobile. Christians are encouraged to be flexible and mobile, constantly progressing towards the heavenly destination. The analogy extends to the tabernacle being visible and constantly on the move, symbolizing Spirit-filled Christians being visible for both believers and the lost world.

The sermon concludes with the anticipation of entering the heavenly Canaan, drawing parallels to the journey of the children of Israel. The promise of pouring out the Spirit in the last days, as mentioned in Joel 2:28-29, is highlighted, suggesting that the time of the catching away of the Bride is imminent.

sermons.title: Isaac – Perfect Trust in the Will of God
sermons.summary:
The sermon reflects on the life of Isaac, focusing on his exemplary trust in the will of God. Isaac's birth, name, and existence were all preordained by God, echoing the predestination of believers in Christ. Isaac remained calm even in the face of mockery and strife, mirroring his trust in God's plan. His peaceful acceptance of his father Abraham's decision regarding his marriage demonstrated his unwavering trust in God's will. Despite challenges, Isaac's reliance on God never wavered. He peacefully resolved disputes and trusted in God's provision, as seen in the well-digging incidents.

The sermon culminates in the poignant story of Isaac's sacrifice on Mount Moriah, mirroring Christ's submission to God's will in Gethsemane. Isaac's complete surrender and acceptance of being bound for sacrifice stand as a powerful example of submission to God's plan. This profound obedience resonates with Jesus' prayer in Gethsemane, showcasing Isaac as a worthy precursor to the ultimate act of submission displayed by Jesus. The sermon highlights Isaac's life as a testament to perfect trust in God's will, inspiring listeners to emulate his faith and reliance on the divine plan.

sermons.title: The Blessed Hope: Unveiling the Rapture in Scripture
sermons.summary:
Welcome, dear friends, to our Bible study on the fascinating and often debated topic of
the Rapture, an event filled with mystery and promise. In this study, we will explore
the biblical foundation of the Rapture, drawing upon various scriptures, including the
catching away of the bride, the global nature of the event, its distinction from the
Second Advent, and the details of the Rapture itself.

sermons.title: No Room in the Manger
sermons.summary:
The sermon explores the profound message behind Luke 2:7, where Jesus is born in a humble manger due to the lack of room in the inn. This humble beginning holds deep symbolism, conveying essential aspects of Jesus' mission and identity.

Firstly, it signifies Jesus' identification with the lowest of the low in the world, showcasing his understanding of human pain and isolation. The fact that there was no room for him in the inn echoes Isaiah 53:3, emphasizing his empathy for those who feel unwelcome and alone.

Secondly, the manger represents God's deliberate choice to embrace poverty. By becoming poor, Jesus demolished the barriers that often accompany wealth, making it possible for anyone, regardless of their financial status, to approach Him. This act of becoming poor for humanity’s sake aligns with 2 Corinthians 8:9, highlighting God's solidarity with the impoverished.

Additionally, the manger illustrates Jesus as the bread of life, feeding spiritual hunger. Just as the manger was a feeding trough for animals, Jesus provides the life-giving sustenance for human souls. Without recognizing their need for this spiritual nourishment, people face spiritual hunger and death, emphasizing the urgency of approaching Jesus.

In essence, the manger challenges societal norms. It invites everyone to approach Jesus not in opulence, but in shared humility and need. By choosing a manger over a grand setting, Jesus opens his arms to all, emphasizing that no one is beyond the reach of his love and salvation. The message encourages listeners to approach Jesus with humility, recognizing their need for his life-giving provision and understanding that he empathetically understands their pain and isolation.

sermons.title: The Glory of the Father is the Same as the Glory of the Son
sermons.summary:
In this sermon on John 17:5, delves deeply into the prayer of Jesus where He asks the Father to glorify Him with the same glory that he had with him before the world’s creation. The sermon challenges mainstream interpretations, asserting that Jesus and the Father are not two distinct individuals but one God in two roles — the Father and the Son.

The preacher emphasizes that Jesus is not addressing the Father as a separate entity. These are not two distinct individuals communicating with one another from within two consciousnesses, but One God who plays two roles in one body – the role of the Father and the role of the Son. The core argument revolves around the Father’s ultimate glory being demonstrated through power over death and eternal life. By raising Himself from the dead after three days, Jesus showcased the Father’s unparalleled glory, proving that he is the Father and hence possesses the glory of the Father.

The sermon connects this profound truth to the metaphorical connection between the Jerusalem Temple and Jesus’ body. When Jesus referred to the Temple as “my Father's house,” He was essentially speaking of His own body. This connection highlights the zeal of the Father for His Temple, His flesh and blood. This sermon emphasizes the need to honor Jesus as both the Son and the Father, urging listeners to approach this truth with reverence, trembling, and love.

Ultimately, the sermon provides a fresh perspective on John 17:5, urging believers to recognize and accept Jesus as the Father Himself. This understanding challenges common interpretations and highlights the divine unity of the Father and the Son, emphasizing the importance of honoring Jesus in this profound revelation.

sermons.title: A Way of Escape
sermons.summary:
The sermon focuses on 1 Corinthians 10:13 and delves into the distinction between trials and evil in the context of God's faithfulness to provide a way of escape for His people.

The Greek word for temptation, peirasmos, encompasses various meanings, including trials, temptation to sin, and afflictions. The sermon emphasizes that trials are common to humanity, and every person, as a part of the human experience, will face trials. The distinction between trials and evil is crucial; trials are challenges that God allows for various reasons, whereas evil is destructive and has no good associated with it.

The sermon offers biblical examples to illustrate the concept of divine escapes. The story of Joseph in Egypt portrays how God provided an escape through favor, enabling Joseph to bear the trials of slavery. The sermon emphasizes the need for individuals to actively look for opportunities or avenues (symbolized by "Potiphars") during trials, rather than dwelling on the problems.

The story of Job illustrates that sometimes God's escape may come in the form of discussions and challenges from friends. Despite the disagreements, these interactions keep individuals engaged and occupied, making the trials more bearable. The narrative of Apostle Paul's journey to Rome demonstrates how God used a storm and subsequent shipwreck as an escape, leading Paul to Malta, where he could preach the Gospel and save souls.

The sermon encourages listeners to recognize that trials are not without purpose. God, in His faithfulness, provides escapes even in the midst of trials. The key lies in actively seeking and recognizing these divine exits, which might come in unexpected forms, enabling believers to bear their trials and fulfill their missions, just as Paul did in Malta. The message reinforces the faithfulness of God in providing ways of escape tailored to each individual's circumstances.

sermons.title: The Mount of Olives: Where Christ Ascended and Will Return
sermons.summary:
The sermon delves into the significance of the Mount of Olives in biblical context, drawing lessons for spiritual understanding. The Mount of Olives is portrayed as a symbol of anointing, representing the spiritual sustenance of God's people.

The sermon explores various instances in the Bible where the Mount of Olives is associated with crucial events. It begins with Jesus teaching in the temple during the day and residing at Mount of Olives at night, highlighting its special importance. Reference is made to Zechariah's prophecy, connecting the mount with anointing and the Lord's return.

In Matthew 24, the chapter about the signs of Christ's return, Jesus sits on the Mount of Olives, signifying the need for believers to be under His anointing to discern the signs accurately. The anointing from the mount protects against worldly deceptions, as seen in the case of King Herod's grand Temple project.

Furthermore, the Mount of Olives is linked to the fulfillment of prophecies. Jesus instructs his disciples from there, fulfilling Zechariah's prophecy about the Messiah's arrival, demonstrating its significance in the revelation of the Messiah's coming.

When Jesus ascends to heaven, the Mount of Olives becomes the departure point, underlining the importance of carrying the anointing (represented by oil) until His return. This anointing, symbolized as oil, signifies the Holy Spirit's presence and is crucial for believers, as highlighted in the parable of the ten virgins. The Mount of Olives becomes the bridge between heaven and earth, emphasizing that believers will leave the world with the anointing of the Holy Spirit and return with Jesus, demonstrating the eternal significance of spiritual anointing.

The sermon concludes by emphasizing the power of the Holy Spirit, depicted as anointing oil, which quickens mortal bodies and ensures spiritual preparedness for Christ's return, emphasizing the intimate connection between the Mount of Olives, anointing, and the return of Jesus.

sermons.title: Jonah - a Reminder of Our Responsibility to the Unsaved World
sermons.summary:
The sermon delves into the story of the prophet Jonah and its relevance to the duties of modern Christians. Jonah, a prophet, was tasked with hearing God's word and conveying it to others. Likewise, Christians bear the responsibility of sharing the message of salvation.

Jonah's attempt to escape God's command by fleeing to Tarshish is likened to modern Christians trying to avoid their duty to reach the unsaved. Jonah's belief that he could elude God's presence is criticized, emphasizing that there is no place beyond God's reach.

The narrative of Jonah's journey on the ship reveals how his behavior led the Gentiles aboard to question his faith. This prompts reflection on how the unsaved world perceives Christians based on their actions and whether they are truly being a light to the world.

When a storm threatens the ship, Jonah's behavior forces the Gentiles to wake him up and pray, highlighting the unsaved world's expectation that Christians should call upon their God. This underscores the need for Christians to be vigilant and active in their faith, especially when surrounded by an unsaved world.

Finally, the sermon discusses God's mercy in providing a great fish to save Jonah, even in his rebellion. This is used as a metaphor to illustrate how God offers opportunities for Christians to fulfill their responsibilities in reaching the unsaved. The sermon concludes with an impassioned call for Christians not to delay in preaching the Gospel, as every day of procrastination may endanger the souls of the unsaved.

In essence, the sermon uses Jonah's story to challenge Christians to take their responsibility of reaching the unsaved seriously, urging them not to evade this duty, but to actively share the message of salvation.

sermons.title: Healing in the Synagogue
sermons.summary:
The sermon centers on the story of a man with a withered hand who attends the synagogue. Despite his physical disability, this man remains faithful in attending the house of God, demonstrating unwavering dedication. His commitment serves as both an inspiration and a rebuke to others who enjoy good health but may neglect their attendance and worship.

The sermon emphasizes that when individuals are unashamed in their faith and worship, God takes notice and rewards their devotion. Just as David showed kindness to Mephibosheth for Jonathan's sake, God values those who are faithful, even if the world perceives them as insignificant.

The focal point of the narrative is the encounter between this man and Jesus. Jesus, impressed by the man's faithfulness, singles him out for healing, despite opposition from the Pharisees who emphasize the Sabbath laws. The man's choice to obey Jesus and stretch forth his withered hand results in its miraculous restoration, highlighting the transformative power of obedience.

The sermon draws a parallel between physical healing and spiritual rebirth, emphasizing that obeying the commands of Jesus, such as Acts 2:38, can restore spiritual deadness and bring new life. It encourages believers to be unashamed and obedient in their faith, even in the face of opposition, as the enemy always opposes salvation.

In summary, the sermon underscores the importance of faithfulness, obedience, and unwavering dedication in worship, using the story of the man with the withered hand as an example. It highlights the transformative power of obedience and the need for believers to stretch forth their hands to receive life-changing blessings from God.

sermons.title: Stand Still and see the Salvation of the Lord!
sermons.summary:
The sermon focuses on the biblical story of the Israelites' exodus from Egypt, emphasizing the idea of separation from the world and salvation. It begins by highlighting how challenging it can be for those who have been deeply entrenched in worldly ways to separate themselves for the Lord. The number 430 is mentioned, signifying a time of permanent and irrevocable separation, drawing parallels with the Israelites' 430 years in slavery in Egypt and the division of the earth in the days of Peleg.

The sermon underscores the importance of faith in God's promise of separation and salvation, even when faced with fear and uncertainty. The Red Sea symbolizes a dramatic and frightening moment when individuals are squeezed between their past sinful lives and the path to salvation. However, the message assures that God stands as a barrier between the past and the glorious future, shielding believers from their tormenting past.

The sermon concludes with an encouragement to stand still and witness the salvation of the Lord. It emphasizes that separation from the world can be painful and turbulent but is essential for understanding the beauty of holiness. Divine intervention is highlighted as the means to break free from the bondage of sin and move towards the Promised Land, with the hope that the path back to a sinful past will be permanently closed. Ultimately, the message encourages believers to rise again, even after falling into sin, and trust in the salvation of the Lord.

sermons.title: Why go to Church?
sermons.summary:
This sermon emphasizes the importance of attending church with the right internal motivations and understanding. The sermon begins by highlighting the idea that going to church is not about external factors like tradition or habit. Instead, it's about recognizing that as believers, you are part of God's household. The church is described as a spiritual family, and attending services should come from a deep internal conviction that you belong to this family. The act of going to church is presented as a battle against the flesh. It's not always easy or convenient, but it's a spiritual commitment. This underscores the idea that true faith requires effort and sacrifice. The sermon emphasizes that the church doesn't need to focus on success, entertainment, modernity, inclusivity, or self-justification. Instead, it should be a place where people worship God wholeheartedly and hold on to their faith in Christ. The importance of worshiping God in church is stressed, referring to Psalm 100. It's in this context that believers receive life and spiritual nourishment.  The sermon references John 6 to highlight that attending church and partaking in communion is a source of eternal life. It's a reminder that Christ is central to the church, and it's through Him that believers find life and sustenance. The sermon concludes by summarizing that the church needs Jesus Christ, faithful believers who hold onto their faith, and believers need to be with Christ. It also includes a call to "fight the good fight" and lean on Christ's strength and love.

In essence, the sermon emphasizes that going to church should be driven by a deep understanding of one's place in God's family and a commitment to worship and spiritual growth, rather than external factors or trends.

sermons.title: Give the Empty Room to Jesus: A Lesson in Hospitality and Faith
sermons.summary:
This message draws inspiration from the biblical accounts of two remarkable individuals: the Shunammite woman and the unnamed host who prepared a guest chamber for the Lord. These stories illustrate the importance of faith, hospitality, and devotion to God.

The Shunammite woman, described as "great," despite her childlessness, made a choice that set her apart. Instead of dwelling on her misfortune, she chose to focus on what truly mattered: her love for God. She was determined to prepare an empty room in her house for the prophet Elisha, a man of God who frequently passed by. Her act of faith demonstrates the principle of seeking first the kingdom of God.

The metaphor of an "empty room" is extended to our own lives. It represents unmet needs, struggles, and challenges that we face. The message encourages us to give these empty rooms to Jesus. In other words, we are called to trust God with our problems and unfulfilled desires.

The story of the unnamed man who prepared a guest chamber for Jesus during the Passover is another powerful example of hospitality and faith. This man's actions symbolize our willingness to make room for Jesus in our lives. He recognized the significance of Jesus and offered his space for the Passover meal.

The message emphasizes that when we give our "empty rooms" to Jesus, we invite Him to fill those spaces with blessings, just as the Shunammite woman's empty room was eventually filled with the laughter of a child. It encourages us to trust God even when faced with challenges, knowing that He will meet our needs in His perfect timing.

The unnamed host's guest chamber for Jesus becomes a symbol of God's divine presence. It was in this room that Jesus shared the life-giving symbolism of His body and blood, and it was where the Holy Spirit was poured out. The lesson here is that when we prepare room for God in our lives, He blesses us in ways beyond our imagination.

Ultimately, the message encourages us to embrace the act of hospitality, faith, and trust in God. Just as Hannah dedicated her child Samuel to God and the Shunammite woman prepared a room for Elisha, we are invited to give our empty rooms to Jesus, trusting that He will fill them with His presence and blessings.

sermons.title: The Church in Babylon: Refusing to Bow
sermons.summary:
The story of Mordecai in the biblical book of Esther is used as a metaphor to illustrate the Church's position in a worldly and hostile environment, symbolized by Babylon. Like Mordecai in Persia, the Church must stand firm and not bow down to the pressures of this world.

Haman, an Agagite and an enemy of the Jews, demanded reverence from all. Everyone bowed to him except Mordecai. This refusal stemmed from Mordecai's understanding of God's decree to fight against Amalek, a symbol of sin. The message is clear: the Church must not compromise with sin, as it brings destruction. Paul's dedication to daily dying to sin is cited as an example.

Babylon represents the contemporary world with its idols and sinful allure. Paul's warnings about the last days' idols are referenced, emphasizing the need to turn away from godless influences. The Church, though present in Babylon, must not adopt its values. Mordecai's watchfulness near the palace serves as a metaphor for the Church's role as spiritual guardians and reminders of God's covenant.

Esther's situation, being Jewish in a foreign land, mirrors the Church's predicament. Just as Esther became queen to a pagan king, the Church, though orphaned in Babylon, is favored by Christ. The promise that God would be a "little sanctuary" for His people, even in foreign lands, is invoked.

The return of the Jewish generation to Jerusalem after 70 years of Babylonian captivity parallels the Church's eventual departure from this world. Despite success in Babylon, many Jews chose to return, understanding God's promises. The Church too awaits the day when the promises of Christ come to fruition, just as those who left Babylon were recorded. The metaphor concludes with a reminder of Jesus' prophecy that some will be taken while others are left, signifying the Church's ultimate separation from the world.

sermons.title: I Will Be to Them a Little Sanctuary
sermons.summary:
In Ezekiel 11:16, God assures His people that even in foreign and hostile lands, He will be their sanctuary. The sermon draws parallels to the Tabernacle of Moses, explaining how it represents God's presence and refuge. Despite challenging surroundings, believers are encouraged to seek this "little sanctuary." The story of Daniel's unwavering prayer in Babylon exemplifies this concept.
